vectorData.altText: 6. The chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is for the face as the nucleus ______________ and nucleus ___________ are for the body. (2 answers; separate with 1 space)

That’s right!  The chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve collects fine touch information from the face and the nucleus gracilis and cuneatus collects similar information the from lower and upper body respectively.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

The trigeminal nerve carries all somatosensory information from the face. The cell bodies of these 1° sensory neurons are in the trigeminal ganglion.
The trigeminal nerve enters the brainstem, and those axons carrying light touch sensation synapse onto the cell bodies of 2° sensory neurons in the chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. The chief sensory nucleus is, for the ipsilateral face, as the nucleus gracilis is for the ipsilateral leg.       
The axons of these 2° sensory neurons decussate     and join the medial lemniscus. Remember, the medial lemniscus is carrying fine touch, vibration and conscious proprioception from the contralateral body, and now the same information from the face joins it.
The axons of the medial lemniscus synapse onto the cell bodies of the 3° neurons in the VP nucleus of the thalamus. The axons of the 3° neurons project to 1° somatosensory cortex.

Or for that matter, as the nucleus cuneatus is for the ipsilateral arm. 
These nuclei all contain 2° sensory neurons encoding light touch.
